questions.text: The gold standard test for the diagnosis of Paroxysmal Nocturnal Hemoglobinuria (PNH) is: (NEET PG 2014)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Flow cytometry

 

Explanation:

 

The gold standard diagnostic test for PNH is the flow cytometry quantification of GPI-linked proteins. This test detects the deficiency of GPI-anchored proteins, such as CD55 (DAF) and CD59 (MIRL), on the surface of red blood cells, which normally protect them from complement-mediated destruction.

 

Diagnosis of PNH:

 

 

Manifestations of PNH:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sucrose Hemolysis Test: Used for screening but not the gold standard.

 

Option C. HAM Test: An older test, less commonly used now.

 

Option D. Genetic Testing: Useful for identifying PIGA gene mutations but not the primary diagnostic tool.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Flow cytometry is the gold standard for diagnosing PNH, detecting deficiencies in CD55 and CD59 on red blood cells.

questions.text: An individual experiences sudden death, and their ECG reveals ST segment elevation in leads V1-V3 along with right bundle branch block. What is the most probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Brugada syndrome

 

Explanation:

 

Brugada syndrome is characterized by a distinctive ECG pattern showing ST segment elevation in right precordial leads (V1-V3) with a right bundle branch block (RBBB) appearance. This genetic disorder affects cardiac sodium channels and predisposes patients to ventricular arrhythmias and sudden cardiac death, especially during sleep or rest. The ECG abnormalities can wax and wane over time and may become more pronounced during acute illness and fever. The pattern includes a coved ST elevation followed by a negative T wave in the right precordial leads.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy (HOCM): Though HOCM is a cause of sudden cardiac death, its ECG findings typically include left ventricular hypertrophy, deep Q waves in lateral and inferior leads, and ST-T wave abnormalities. It does not produce the characteristic ST elevation in V1-V3 with RBBB pattern seen in Brugada syndrome.

 

Option B. Aortic valve stenosis: While aortic stenosis can cause sudden death, its ECG findings typically include left ventricular hypertrophy and ST-T wave abnormalities in lateral leads. It doesn't cause the specific pattern of ST elevation in V1-V3 with RBBB seen in this case.

 

Option D. Ashman phenomenon: This is a conduction abnormality characterized by aberrant ventricular conduction (typically RBBB morphology) following a short-long R-R interval sequence. It is not associated with ST elevation in V1-V3 and is not a cause of sudden cardiac death.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Brugada syndrome presents with a distinctive ECG pattern of ST elevation in right precordial leads (V1-V3) with RBBB appearance and is an important cause of sudden cardiac death in structurally normal hearts, especially in young adults.

questions.text: Which enzyme catalyzes the conversion of a compound into IP3 and DAG? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Phospholipase C

 

Explanation:

 

Phospholipase C (PLC) is the enzyme that catalyzes the hydrolysis of phosphatidylinositol 4,5-bisphosphate (PIP2) in the cell membrane to generate two important second messengers: inositol 1,4,5-trisphosphate (IP3) and diacylglycerol (DAG). This reaction occurs when a ligand binds to a receptor (either G-protein coupled or tyrosine kinase receptor) that activates PLC. Subsequently, IP3 diffuses to the endoplasmic reticulum where it triggers calcium release, while DAG remains in the membrane to activate protein kinase C.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option a. Adenylyl cyclase: This enzyme catalyzes the conversion of ATP to cyclic AMP (cAMP), not IP3 and DAG. It's activated by stimulatory G-proteins (Gs) after receptor binding and generates cAMP as a second messenger.
  • Option b. Guanylyl cyclase: This enzyme catalyzes the formation of cyclic GMP (cGMP) from GTP. It exists in both membrane-bound and soluble forms, with the latter activated by nitric oxide. It does not produce IP3 or DAG.
  • Option d. Phospholipase A: This enzyme cleaves fatty acids from the sn-2 position of membrane phospholipids, generating arachidonic acid and lysophospholipids. It's involved in the production of eicosanoids but not IP3 or DAG.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The phosphoinositide signaling pathway involves phospholipase C-mediated hydrolysis of PIP2 to generate two distinct second messengers (IP3 and DAG) that work in tandem to increase intracellular calcium and activate protein kinase C, coordinating comprehensive cellular responses.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Churg-Strauss Syndrome is not true?(NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Intravascular granulomas

 

 

Explanation:

 

Churg-Strauss Syndrome, now known as Eosinophilic Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (EGPA), is characterized by extravascular granulomas, not intravascular granulomas. EGPA features granulomatous reactions that are present in tissues or even within the walls of vessels, but they are not typically found inside the vessel lumen (intravascular).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Asthma: Asthma is a characteristic feature of EGPA. Pulmonary findings dominate the clinical picture, with severe asthmatic attacks being a hallmark presentation. Asthma typically occurs early in the disease course and is present in virtually all patients with this condition.

 

Option B. Peripheral eosinophilia:  Peripheral eosinophilia is a hallmark laboratory finding in EGPA. The characteristic finding is striking eosinophilia, which reaches levels >1000 cells/Î¼L in >80% of patients. This is a key diagnostic criterion for the condition.

 

Option C. Vasculitis of multiple organ systems: EGPA involves vasculitis affecting multiple organ systems. The necrotizing vasculitis involves small- and medium-sized muscular arteries, capillaries, veins, and venules. Common sites of involvement include lungs, skin, cardiovascular system, kidneys, peripheral nervous system, and gastrointestinal tract.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Eosinophilic Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (Churg-Strauss) is characterized by the triad of asthma, peripheral eosinophilia, and vasculitis, with extravascular granulomatous inflammation being a key histopathologic finding. These granulomas are present in tissues or vessel walls, not within the vessel lumen.

questions.text: A 36-year-old male came with complaints of ascending weakness in both lower limb and upper body. There was no history of trauma. Which of the following is the next investigation? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Serum Potassium

 

Disturbance in serum potassium levels (hypokalemia or hyperkalemia) present with ascending muscle weakness.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Serum Magnesium: Incorrect for this scenario as disturbances in magnesium typically cause tetany (muscle spasms) when low and generalized weakness when high, but are less directly linked to the type of ascending muscle weakness described.

 

Option C. Serum Sodium: Incorrect because changes in serum sodium levels generally affect neurological function but do not typically cause muscular weakness.

 

Option D. Serum Calcium: Incorrect as calcium imbalances would more likely cause tetany (from hypocalcemia) or symptoms like fatigue, depression, and cardiac arrhythmias (from hypercalcemia), rather than ascending muscle weakness.

 

Educational Objective:
 

The disturbances in serum potassium levels can manifest as muscle weakness, making it a vital test in cases of unexplained, ascending muscle weakness without trauma.

choices.text: Serum ceruloplasmin levels
Serum copper levels

questions.text: A child presents with hepatitis and progressive neurological degeneration. A picture of his eye has been provided below. Among the following options, what would be the initial step regarding the investigations done for this child's diagnosis? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Serum ceruloplasmin levels

 

The image of the eye, showing a possible Kayser-Fleischer ring, along with symptoms of hepatitis and progressive neurological degeneration, strongly suggests Wilson disease. Wilson disease is a genetic disorder affecting copper metabolism. The initial screening test in suspected cases is the measurement of serum ceruloplasmin levels, as ceruloplasmin is the primary copper-carrying protein in the blood, and levels are typically reduced in Wilson disease.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Serum copper levels: This test is used to further support the diagnosis after abnormalities in ceruloplasmin levels are noted. Total serum copper is typically low in Wilson disease, but free copper is elevated due to the low ceruloplasmin levels.

 

Option C. Enzyme assay: Not relevant for Wilson disease, which involves a defect in copper transport rather than an enzyme deficiency.

 

Option D. Karyotyping: Also not relevant, as Wilson disease is related to mutations in the ATP7B gene, not chromosomal abnormalities.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a child presenting with hepatitis and neurological symptoms, the presence of a Kayser-Fleischer ring strongly suggests Wilson disease. The first diagnostic step is to measure serum ceruloplasmin levels.

questions.text: Which of the following is least useful in the management of a patient with Thalamic Dejerine syndrome?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ibuprofen

 

Explanation:

 

Thalamic Dejerine syndrome, also known as Dejerine-Roussy syndrome, is characterized by chronic, intense pain on the contralateral side of the body following a thalamic stroke. The pain is often resistant to typical analgesics and requires specific management with medications that target neuropathic pain.

 

Medications useful in managing Thalamic Dejerine syndrome include:

 

  • Amitriptyline: A tricyclic antidepressant effective in treating neuropathic pain.
  • Gabapentin: An anticonvulsant used to manage neuropathic pain.
  • Carbamazepine: An anticonvulsant also used for neuropathic pain management.

 

Ibuprofen, a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID), is not effective for neuropathic pain and therefore is the least useful in managing Thalamic Dejerine syndrome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A, B & C are effective for neuropathic pain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ibuprofen is least useful for managing Thalamic Dejerine syndrome, which requires medications that target neuropathic pain.

questions.text: Identify the type of ANA staining pattern shown in the image below? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Centromeric

 

The centromeric pattern is characterized by distinct dots in the nucleus, corresponding to centromeres during cell division. This pattern is associated with anti-centromere antibodies (ACA), commonly seen in limited cutaneous scleroderma (CREST syndrome). ACA antibody is  correlate with pulmonary hypertension seen in patients with limited disease. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Homogenous: Diffuse staining of the nucleus, seen with anti-ds DNA antibodies or anti-histone antibodies.
 

Option C. Speckled: Numerous fine or coarse speckles, a kind of quite nonspecific, associated with various antibodies such as anti-SEL70, anti-JOAN, and anti-SMITH antibodies, etc
 

Option D. Nucleolar: Prominent nucleolar staining, quite nonspecific, seen with Anti-PM-Scl antibody, an overlap antibody.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Centromeric pattern in ANA staining is associated with anti-centromere antibodies and limited scleroderma.

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in tumor lysis syndrome ? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hypercalcemia 

 

Tumor lysis syndrome occurs due to destruction of large no of rapidly proliferating neoplstic cells. It is characterised by Hyperuricemia, hyperkalemia , hyperphosphasphatemia, hypocalcemia, acidosis, acute renal failure.

 

It mainly occurs after initiation of chemotherapy and is diagnosed by Cairo bishop criteria (includes both lab and clinical features)

 

Management includes - allopurinol , rasburicase along with aggressive hydration .

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hyperphosphatemia: Typically occurs as phosphate is released from lysed tumor cells.

 

Option B. Hyperuricemia: Results from the metabolism of nucleic acids from destroyed cells.

 

Option D. Hyperkalemia: Occurs due to the release of potassium from the intracellular to the extracellular space.

 

Educational Objective:


In tumor lysis syndrome, the rapid breakdown of tumor cells leads to hypocalcemia, not hypercalcemia, making this the key distinguishing feature in identifying the condition. Management strategies like hydration, use of allopurinol, or rasburicase are critical in preventing renal failure and other serious complications.

questions.text: High anion gap acidosis with low bicarbonate levels is seen in all the following conditions except: (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Renal Disorders

 

High anion gap metabolic acidosis (HAGMA) is characterized by the accumulation of acids in the body, which are not accompanied by an increase in other measured anions, thus increasing the anion gap. This condition typically involves a decrease in bicarbonate as the body tries to buffer the excess hydrogen ions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lactic Acidosis: This condition occurs when lactate levels increase in the bloodstream during tissue hypoxia, commonly seen in shock or severe dehydration, and results in HAGMA.

 

Option C. Diabetic Ketoacidosis: In DKA, the body produces high levels of blood acids called ketones, which lead to HAGMA.

 

Option D. Salicylate Poisoning: In salicylate toxicity, especially at higher doses, metabolic acidosis occurs due to uncoupling of oxidative phosphorylation, leading to HAGMA. Initially, salicylate stimulates the respiratory center causing a respiratory alkalosis, which can be followed by metabolic acidosis at higher doses.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Renal disorders typically cause non-anion gap metabolic acidosis (NAGMA) due to an inability to excrete acid or conserve bicarbonate, rather than high anion gap acidosis seen in conditions like lactic acidosis, diabetic ketoacidosis, and salicylate poisoning.

questions.text: Cushing's ulcers are seen in? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Head injury

 

Cushing's ulcers are specifically associated with head injuries or conditions that lead to increased intracranial pressure (ICP). The mechanism involves vagal nerve stimulation due to the increased ICP, which in turn causes an overproduction of gastric acid leading to the development of ulcers. This is distinct from other types of stress-related gastric ulcers.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Burns: This type of ulcer is known as Curling's ulcer, which occurs in response to severe burns and is related to the physiological stress and possible hypovolemia resulting from the burn injury, not the brain injury-related mechanism of Cushing's ulcers.

 

Option B. Stress: While stress can indeed lead to gastric ulcers, the specific term "Cushing's ulcers" is not used in this context. General stress-related ulcers do not typically involve the mechanism of vagal stimulation due to increased ICP.

 

Option D. Cell necrosis: This is a general process that can occur in many pathological conditions but does not specifically relate to the formation of Cushing's ulcers.

 

Educational Objective:


Cushing's ulcers are a specific type of peptic ulcer that occurs due to increased intracranial pressure resulting from head injuries. Recognizing this condition is important for managing patients with significant neurological trauma to prevent and treat these potentially serious gastrointestinal complications.

questions.text: The absence of loud S1 in mitral stenosis would indicate all of the following, except: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Mild mitral stenosis

 

The first heart sound (S1) is produced by the closure of the mitral and tricuspid valves at the beginning of systole. In mitral stenosis, the loudness of S1 can vary depending on several factors. A loud S1 is typically associated with the early stages of mitral stenosis when the valve leaflets are still relatively mobile. However, in certain conditions, S1 can become softer.

 

In mild mitral stenosis without significant calcification usually results in a loud S1. This is because the mitral valve leaflets are still relatively mobile and can close forcefully. Therefore, mild mitral stenosis is the correct exception in this context, as it does not typically cause a soft S1.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Calcified valve: When the mitral valve becomes calcified, it loses its mobility. This results in a softer S1 because the valve leaflets are not able to close rapidly or forcefully.

 

Option B. Aortic regurgitation: Aortic regurgitation can lead to an increased preload in the left ventricle, which can in turn affect the closure of the mitral valve, making S1 softer. Additionally, mitral regurgitation, which often coexists with mitral stenosis, can also soften S1.

 

Option C. First degree heart block: In first degree AV block, there is a prolonged PR interval. This delayed conduction can lead to a less forceful closure of the mitral valve, resulting in a softer S1.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In mitral stenosis, a loud S1 is typically seen in the early stages with mobile valves, while a soft S1 can indicate valve calcification, aortic regurgitation, or first degree heart block. Mild mitral stenosis without calcification usually results in a loud S1

questions.text: The most common cause of Cushing's disease in a 60-year-old male is: (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pituitary microadenoma

 

Cushing's disease is specifically caused by a pituitary adenoma that secretes excess adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH). This excess ACTH stimulates the adrenal glands to produce more cortisol, leading to the symptoms of Cushing's syndrome. In the context of Cushing's disease, the term always refers to a pituitary origin.

 

Cushing's syndrome, on the other hand, can have various causes:

 

  • Exogenous Cushing's syndrome: Due to external sources of cortisol, such as prolonged use of glucocorticoid medications.
  • Endogenous Cushing's syndrome: subdivided into â 
    • ACTH-dependent - High ACTH levels stimulate cortisol production, associated with symptoms like hyperpigmentation. (e.g. pituitary adenoma/ cushingâs disease, ectopic ACTH secretion)
    • ACTH-independent - Low or normal ACTH levels, with cortisol overproduction directly from the adrenal glands (e.g., adrenal adenoma, adrenal carcinoma).

 

Among the endogenous causes, pituitary adenomas (Cushing's disease) are the most common, responsible for about 60-65% of cases. Ectopic ACTH secretion accounts for about 20-25% of cases, and adrenal tumors are responsible for 5-10% of cases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Small-cell lung cancer: Can cause ectopic ACTH syndrome but is not the most common cause of Cushing's disease.

 

Option B. Adrenal tumor: Can cause Cushing's syndrome but is less common compared to pituitary adenomas.

 

Option C. Ectopic ACTH syndrome: Can be caused by various tumors, including small-cell lung cancer, but is not as common as pituitary adenomas in causing Cushing's disease. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pituitary microadenoma is the most common cause of Cushing's disease, which is characterized by excess ACTH production from the pituitary gland.

choices.text: Risk of thrombosis strongly correlates with the degree of thrombocytosis
It is protective against H. pylori infection
Generalized pruritus is a consequence of mast cell activation by JAK 2 mutation
Acute myeloid leukemia is the most common cause of mortality

questions.text: Which of the following statements about polycythemia vera is true? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Generalized pruritus is a consequence of mast cell activation by JAK 2 mutation

 

Polycythemia vera (PV) is a myeloproliferative neoplasm characterized by the overproduction of red blood cells. It is commonly associated with a mutation in the JAK2 gene, which can also affect other cell types, including mast cells. Activation of these cells can lead to the release of histamine, which is thought to contribute to the itching or pruritus often experienced by patients, particularly after warm baths or showers.

 

Myeloproliferative neoplasms include PCV, CML, and PMF.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Risk of thrombosis strongly correlates with the degree of thrombocytosis: Incorrect. Although thrombocytosis is present in polycythemia vera, thrombosis risk correlates more significantly with leukocytosis and the presence of JAK2 mutation rather than solely with thrombocytosis.

 

Option B. It is protective against H. pylori infection: Incorrect. There is no evidence to suggest that polycythemia vera provides protection against H. pylori infection. Patients with PV actually may have an increased risk of gastrointestinal issues.

 

Option D. Acute myeloid leukemia is the most common cause of mortality: Incorrect. While patients with polycythemia vera do have an increased risk of transformation to acute myeloid leukemia (AML), the most common cause of mortality in these patients is thrombotic events such as heart attack or stroke.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Generalized pruritus in polycythemia vera, exacerbated by warmth or bathing, is a well-known symptom related to mast cell activation due to the JAK2 mutation. This mutation is a hallmark of the disease and leads to several systemic effects, including increased histamine release, which contributes to pruritus.

 

All MPN can develop AML, Myelofibrosis in the course of the disease.

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient with heart failure and poorly controlled type 2 diabetes (HbA1c of 7.8%) presents with progressive dyspnea. Which is the preferred antidiabetic drug? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Dapagliflozin

 

Dapagliflozin is a sodium-glucose co-transporter-2 (SGLT2) inhibitor that has shown significant benefits in patients with heart failure, particularly heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF). SGLT2 inhibitors, including dapagliflozin and empagliflozin, have been demonstrated to improve survival, reduce heart failure hospitalizations, and delay the progression of heart failure. These benefits make SGLT2 inhibitors the preferred choice for patients with both type 2 diabetes and heart failure.

 

Four Pillars in the Management of HFrEF (Heart Failure with Reduced Ejection Fraction):

 

  1. ARNIs and ACE Inhibitors/ARBs:
    • ARNIs (e.g., Sacubitril/Valsartan) are preferred.
    • ACE Inhibitors/ARBs are also used.
  2. Beta Blockers:
    • Metoprolol
    • Bisoprolol
    • Carvedilol
  3. MRAs (Mineralocorticoid Receptor Antagonists):
    • Spironolactone
    • Eplerenone
  4. SGLT2 Inhibitors:
    • Empagliflozin
    • Dapagliflozin

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Glimepiride: This is a sulfonylurea that primarily helps in lowering blood glucose by stimulating insulin secretion. It does not provide the cardiovascular benefits seen with SGLT2 inhibitors and can increase the risk of hypoglycemia.

 

Option C. Metformin: While metformin is a first-line therapy for type 2 diabetes and has some cardiovascular benefits, it is not specifically indicated for improving heart failure outcomes.

 

Option D. Sitagliptin: This is a dipeptidyl peptidase-4 (DPP-4) inhibitor used to manage blood glucose levels. It does not provide the same level of heart failure benefit as SGLT2 inhibitors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For patients with type 2 diabetes and heart failure, SGLT2 inhibitors like dapagliflozin are the preferred antidiabetic medications due to their proven benefits in reducing heart failure progression, hospitalizations, and mortality.

choices.text: Cannot comment without d-dimer values

questions.text: A 53-year-old woman underwent hip replacement surgery. A week after the surgery, the patient developed swelling of the legs associated with pain on palpation. Her heart rate is 70 beats per min. There is no history of hemoptysis or significant weight loss. There is no previous history of pulmonary embolism. What is the risk of developing pulmonary embolism in the patient based on Well's score? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. High

 

The Well's Score is a clinical tool used to estimate the probability of a pulmonary embolism (PE). The score is calculated based on various risk factors and clinical features. In this patient's case:

 

Modified wells criteria: 3 + 3 + 1.5 = 7.5 (>4) suggestive of high risk.

 

 

Inference:

 

  • 4: PE Likely
  • < 4: PE unlikely

 

Educational Objective:

 

When assessing the risk of pulmonary embolism, especially in postoperative patients presenting with symptoms suggestive of DVT, it is essential to consider both the clinical presentation and the surgical history. The Wells score is a valuable tool in stratifying the risk and guiding further diagnostic testing and management. In this scenario, the patient falls into a high-risk category, indicating that further immediate investigation, typically with imaging like a CT pulmonary angiogram, is warranted.

 

Reference - UpToDate/Wells score

questions.text: Patient develops severe migratory joint pain after an attack of acute rheumatic fever. How will you manage this patient? (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Aspirin

 

Explanation

 

The correct answer is Aspirin. Acute rheumatic fever commonly presents with migratory polyarthritis, which is characterized by severe joint pain that moves from one joint to another.

 

The treatment of choice for this arthritis is nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), with aspirin being the most effective and commonly used. Aspirin helps to reduce inflammation and pain associated with the arthritis of acute rheumatic fever.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Furosemide: This is a diuretic and is not used for the management of arthritis in acute rheumatic fever. It may be used in cases of heart failure associated with rheumatic carditis.

 

Option B. Digoxin: This is a cardiac glycoside used in heart failure and atrial fibrillation. It is not used for managing arthritis in acute rheumatic fever.

 

Option D. Amiodarone: This is an antiarrhythmic medication and has no role in the management of arthritis in acute rheumatic fever.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The primary treatment for severe migratory joint pain (arthritis) in acute rheumatic fever is the use of NSAIDs, with aspirin being the drug of choice due to its effectiveness in reducing inflammation and pain.

questions.text: A 60-year gentleman was referred from outside hospital to AIIMS ER after he developed sudden onset quadriparesis. In hospital patient was treated with 3%NaCl, Oral tolvaptan. Initial metabolic panel revealed Na: 115 mEq/L, K: 2.8 mEq/L, Cl: 85 mEq/L with normal TSH, CBC, RFT, LFT.  What is the most likely cause for this patient's condition?  (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Osmotic demyelination syndrome

 

Previously called central pontine myelinolysis. It occurs due to rapid correction of Chronic Hyponatremia (>8 mg/dL).

 

Timing: 2-6 days after rapid correction.

 

Rx: Irreversible. Desmopressin clamp if overcorrection in q6h Na values.  

 

Mechanism:

 

1. In Hyponatremia

 

 

2. On sudden correction:

 

 

Risk factors:

 

  1. Serum sodium â¤ 105 mEq/L
  2. Concurrent hypokalemia
  3. Chronic excess alcohol intake
  4. Acute or chronic hepatic disease
  5. Malnourishment

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Brain infarct: Not directly suggested by the rapid onset of symptoms following electrolyte correction.

 

Option B. Brainstem injury: Could be considered but is less likely without trauma or vascular insult history.

 

Option D. Rare cause of hypernatremia: Not applicable as the condition involves the rapid correction of hyponatremia, not hypernatremia itself.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rapid correction of chronic hyponatremia should be avoided to prevent the severe neurological complications associated with osmotic demyelination syndrome. Control and monitoring of serum sodium levels are crucial during treatment.

 

Reference - Harrison/Electrolytes/Chap 53

questions.text: A patient came with hypoxemia and a normal alveolar-arterial oxygen gradient. What can be the cause? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hypoventilation

 

Hypoxemia with a normal alveolar-arterial (A-a) oxygen gradient typically points to specific causes where the alveolar oxygen (PAO2) and arterial oxygen (PaO2) levels remain proportionate. In this scenario, the primary causes are hypoventilation and situations involving low inspired oxygen tension (low FiO2).

 

Hypoventilation: This condition leads to hypoxemia due to inadequate ventilation. When ventilation is insufficient, the amount of oxygen entering the alveoli drops, leading to a corresponding decrease in the amount of oxygen diffusing into the blood, resulting in hypoxemia. However, because the underlying issue is with ventilation and not with oxygen diffusion or blood flow, the A-a gradient remains normal.

 

Low FiO2 or Low Barometric Pressure: This can occur in scenarios such as high altitude where the barometric pressure is low, leading to reduced oxygen availability in the air. However, these situations were not explicitly listed among the answer choices.

 

According to the reference paragraph, other conditions like ventilation/perfusion (V/Q) mismatch, diffusion limitation, and alveolar membrane damage, cause an increased A-a gradient due to impaired oxygen transfer across the alveolar membrane or mismatched ventilation and perfusion in the lungs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Right to left shunt: This condition causes hypoxemia due to blood bypassing the lungs and not getting oxygenated. It leads to an increased A-a gradient because the oxygen content of the arterial blood is significantly lower compared to the alveolar oxygen level.

 

Option B. Ventilation/Perfusion mismatch: This condition results from areas of the lung receiving oxygen but not perfused with blood or areas perfused with blood but not receiving oxygen. It causes an increased A-a gradient due to ineffective oxygen transfer to the blood.

 

Option D. Alveolar membrane damage: This results in impaired oxygen diffusion across the alveolar-capillary membrane, leading to an increased A-a gradient as oxygen transfer from alveoli to blood is hindered.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hypoventilation is a primary cause of hypoxemia with a normal alveolar-arterial oxygen gradient.

questions.text: A woman presents to you with fever, arthralgia, ulcers, fatigue for the past six months, and new-onset hematuria. Urine examination reveals RBC casts and proteinuria. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Lupus nephritis

 

Lupus nephritis is a common complication of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), an autoimmune disease that can affect multiple organ systems. The patient's symptoms of fever, arthralgia, ulcers, and fatigue, combined with new-onset hematuria and findings of RBC casts and proteinuria in the urine, are indicative of systemic involvement typical of lupus nephritis.

 

Lupus nephritis is characterized by inflammation of the kidneys, often leading to hematuria, proteinuria, and renal impairment.

 

Next Step -

 

Conducting an ANA (antinuclear antibody) test.

 

Performing an anti-dsDNA (anti-double stranded DNA) test, which is noted as being very specific and correlates with lupus nephritis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute interstitial nephritis: This condition typically presents with WBC casts rather than RBC casts in the urine and is not usually associated with systemic symptoms like fever, arthralgia, or ulcers.

 

Option B. Poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN): While PSGN can cause RBC casts and proteinuria, it is generally a renal-limited condition and does not present with systemic symptoms like fever, arthralgia, and ulcers.

 

Option D. IgA nephropathy: IgA nephropathy is also a renal-limited condition and typically does not present with systemic symptoms. It is characterized by recurrent episodes of gross hematuria, usually following upper respiratory infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lupus nephritis should be suspected in patients with systemic lupus erythematosus who present with renal symptoms such as hematuria and proteinuria, especially when accompanied by systemic symptoms like fever, arthralgia, ulcers, and fatigue. Further testing, including ANA and anti-dsDNA antibodies, is warranted to confirm the diagnosis.

questions.text: The given ECG depicts which of the following conditions:  (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ventricular bigeminy

 

Premature ventricular complex (PVCs)- Have following features

 

  • Broad QRS complex (>120ms) with abnormal morphology
  • Premature- i.e., occurs earlier than would be expected for the next sinus impulse
  • Discordant ST segment and T wave changes.
  • Usually followed by a full compensatory pause

 

PVCs often occur in repeating pattern: bigeminy, trigeminy, quadrigeminy

 

Couplet: 2 consecutive PVCs is known as couplet

 

Triplet: 3 consecutive PVCs is known as triplet

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. PSVT (Paroxysmal Supraventricular Tachycardia): This condition would show a fast, regular heart rate with narrow QRS complexes; not observed here.

 

Option C. P pulmonale: This involves peaked P waves seen in leads II, III, and aVF, typically due to right atrial enlargement; not evident in this ECG.

 

Option D. Re-entrant atrial fibrillation: Would show an irregularly irregular rhythm without consistent P waves; this is not present in the ECG provided.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ventricular bigeminy is identified by the presence of alternating normal sinus beats and PVCs, each PVC typically followed by a compensatory pause, creating a repeating pattern of one normal beat followed by one abnormal beat.

questions.text: Gastric lavage is contraindicated in which of the following poisoning? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hydrocarbon

 

Gastric lavage is contraindicated in two types of poisoning: Hydrocarbon and corrosive poisoning. 

 

Hydrocarbons are substances such as gasoline, kerosene, or certain cleaning agents, which are highly volatile and can easily be aspirated into the lungs during the procedure. This can lead to severe chemical pneumonitis and other respiratory complications, making the risks of gastric lavage significantly higher than any potential benefits.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Phenytoin: Gastric lavage is not typically contraindicated in phenytoin poisoning. While it is not the first line of treatment, it can be considered if the patient presents soon after ingestion.

 

Option C. Unknown poisoning within 1 hour: For unknown poisoning, especially if within 1 hour of ingestion, gastric lavage might still be considered, although it is generally falling out of favor due to risks and effectiveness. However, it is not specifically contraindicated.

 

Option D. Paracetamol: Gastric lavage is not contraindicated in paracetamol (acetaminophen) poisoning. The mainstay of treatment for paracetamol poisoning is N-acetylcysteine (NAC) administration, but if the patient presents early, gastric lavage can be considered.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gastric lavage is contraindicated in hydrocarbon poisoning due to the high risk of aspiration and subsequent chemical pneumonitis. In any case of poisoning, the potential risks and benefits of gastric lavage must be carefully considered.

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in MEN 2B syndrome? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Parathyroid adenoma

 

Parathyroid adenomas are not seen in MEN 2B. Parathyroid adenomas are typically associated with MEN 1 and MEN 2A syndromes, where hyperparathyroidism is a common feature due to the involvement of the parathyroid glands.

 

Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia type 2B (MEN 2B) is a genetic syndrome characterized by specific clinical features. It is also known as the "Triple M syndrome" because it typically presents with the following:

 

  • Mucosal Neuromas: These are benign growths on the mucous membranes and are a hallmark of MEN 2B.
  • Marfanoid Habitus: This refers to a body habitus resembling Marfan syndrome, with features like long limbs, a tall, slender build, and hyperflexible joints.
  • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (MTC): This is a type of thyroid cancer commonly associated with MEN 2B.

 

Other features that can be seen in MEN 2B include pheochromocytomas (tumors of the adrenal glands) and ganglioneuromas (tumors of the nerve cells).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Megacolon: Megacolon can be associated with MEN 2B due to the presence of ganglioneuromatosis affecting the gastrointestinal tract.

 

Option C. Mucosal Neuroma: As mentioned, mucosal neuromas are a classic feature of MEN 2B and one of the reasons it is called "triple M syndrome."

 

Option D. Marfanoid Habitus: This characteristic physical appearance is commonly seen in MEN 2B patients.

 

Educational Objective:

 

MEN 2B syndrome, also known as "triple M syndrome," is characterized by mucosal neuromas, marfanoid habitus, and medullary thyroid carcinoma, but does not involve parathyroid adenomas.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy presents with recurrent infections, including delayed separation of the umbilical cord at birth, recurrent skin and mucosal infections, and poor wound healing. Laboratory findings show an absence of CD18 on leukocyte flow cytometry. What is the primary suspicion based on these findings? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Leukocyte Adhesion Defect (LAD)

 

Explanation:


Leukocyte Adhesion Defect (LAD) is a rare immunodeficiency characterized by defects in leukocyte migration and adhesion, due to mutations affecting integrins such as CD18 (LAD type 

 

1) Clinical features include:

  • Delayed separation of the umbilical cord: A hallmark feature.
  • Recurrent skin and mucosal infections: Often without pus formation due to impaired leukocyte migration.
  • Poor wound healing: Caused by defective leukocyte adhesion and migration to sites of infection.

 

Diagnosis is confirmed by flow cytometry showing the absence or reduced expression of CD18 on leukocytes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chronic Granulomatous Disease: Incorrect because CGD involves defects in the NADPH oxidase enzyme, leading to impaired oxidative killing of pathogens, which is detected by an abnormal DHR or NBT test. It presents with recurrent abscesses and lymphadenitis, not delayed cord separation.

 

Option B. Severe Combined Immunodeficiency: Incorrect because SCID presents with profound defects in both T- and B-lymphocyte immunity, leading to severe infections early in life, and does not involve delayed cord separation or lack of pus formation.

 

Option D. Chediak-Higashi Syndrome: Incorrect because Chediak-Higashi syndrome involves defects in lysosomal trafficking, leading to giant granules in leukocytes and recurrent infections, as well as features like partial albinism and neurologic symptoms, which are not seen here.

 

Educational Objective:


Leukocyte Adhesion Defect (LAD) is characterized by delayed umbilical cord separation, recurrent infections without pus formation, and poor wound healing. The diagnosis is confirmed by the absence or reduced expression of CD18 on leukocytes in flow cytometry. Early recognition is crucial to prevent severe complications

choices.text: Primary hyperparathyroidism
Vitamin D toxicity
Familial hypocalciuric hypercalcemia

questions.text: Most common cause of hypercalcemia in hospitalized patients is (INICET Nov 2023
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Malignancy

 

Explanation:  

 

In hospitalized patients, the most common cause of hypercalcemia is malignancy. Malignancy-associated hypercalcemia often results from the secretion of parathyroid hormone-related peptide (PTHrP) by cancer cells, which mimics the effects of parathyroid hormone, leading to increased calcium levels. This is frequently seen in cancers such as breast cancer, lung cancer, and multiple myeloma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Primary hyperparathyroidism: This is the most common cause of hypercalcemia in outpatients but not in hospitalized patients. It is characterized by elevated levels of parathyroid hormone (PTH) due to parathyroid gland hyperplasia, adenoma, or carcinoma.

 

Option C. Vitamin D toxicity: Hypercalcemia can occur due to excessive intake of vitamin D, leading to increased intestinal absorption of calcium. However, it is not the most common cause in hospitalized patients.

 

Option D. Familial hypocalciuric hypercalcemia: This is a rare genetic condition characterized by benign hypercalcemia with low urinary calcium excretion. It mimics primary hyperparathyroidism but is less common and typically not seen as the most frequent cause of hypercalcemia in hospitalized patients.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Malignancy is the most common cause of hypercalcemia in hospitalized patients, often due to the secretion of PTHrP by cancer cells.

choices.text: BP > 160/90 mmHg with one anti-hypertensive
BP > 140/90 mmHg with one anti-hypertensive
BP > 140/90 mmHg with three or more anti hypertensives
BP > 160/90 mmHg with three or more anti hypertensives

questions.text: Resistant hypertension is defined as? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) BP > 140/90 mmHg with three or more anti hypertensives.

 

Resistant hypertension is defined as blood pressure that remains above goal despite the concurrent use of three anti-hypertensive agents of different classes. Typically, one of the three medications should be a diuretic, and all agents should be prescribed at optimal dose amounts. The threshold set for defining resistant hypertension is blood pressure greater than 140/90 mmHg.

 

Resistant hypertension indicates a situation where blood pressure control is inadequate despite the use of multiple medications, which can pose significant risks for cardiovascular complications and requires careful evaluation for secondary causes. This includes assessing for white-coat HTN/Pseudo HTN, medication adherence, lifestyle factors, and secondary causes of hypertension like renal artery stenosis, endocrine disorders, or medication-induced hypertension.

 

Home BP monitoring, ABPM (Ambulatory BP monitoring) can help in optimization of drugs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Resistant HTN refers to BP > 140/90 mmHg despite three anti-HTN, one being a diuretic.

 

Reference - Harrison 21E/Cardiology/Hypertensive Disease/ chap 277

questions.text: A male patient had feeble femoral pulses with an upper-limb blood pressure of 186/90 mmHg. Chest X-ray showed enlarged intercostal arteries. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Coarctation of aorta

 

Coarctation of the aorta is a congenital condition characterized by the narrowing of the aorta, which causes an obstruction to blood flow. This condition leads to high blood pressure in the arteries that are proximal to the narrowing (upper limbs) and lower blood pressure in the arteries distal to the narrowing (lower limbs).

 

The key findings in this scenario include:

 

  • Feeble femoral pulses: Due to reduced blood flow past the coarctation.
  • Upper limb hypertension: Caused by increased resistance proximal to the coarctation.
  • Chest X-ray showing enlarged intercostal arteries: These develop as collateral circulation to bypass the coarctation, which can cause rib notching seen on X-ray.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Atrial septal defect (ASD): An ASD is a hole in the septum between the heart's atria. It typically causes a left-to-right shunt and can lead to increased pulmonary blood flow and right heart overload. It does not cause differential blood pressure between limbs or enlarged intercostal arteries.

 

Option C. Bicuspid aortic valve: A bicuspid aortic valve is a congenital valve anomaly that can lead to aortic stenosis or regurgitation but does not typically cause differential blood pressure between the limbs or enlarged intercostal arteries.

 

Option D. Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA): A PDA is a persistent opening between the aorta and the pulmonary artery. It causes a continuous murmur and can lead to heart failure if significant but does not cause differential blood pressure or enlarged intercostal arteries.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Coarctation of the aorta should be suspected in patients with a significant difference in blood pressure between the upper and lower limbs, feeble femoral pulses, and chest X-ray findings of enlarged intercostal arteries, indicating collateral circulation.

questions.text: What is the most common site of abdominal tuberculosis? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ileocecal junction

 

The ileocecal junction is the most common site of abdominal tuberculosis. This area, which includes the terminal ileum and the beginning of the large intestine (cecum), is particularly susceptible to infection by Mycobacterium tuberculosis. The lymphoid tissue in this region provides a favorable environment for the bacteria to proliferate.

 

Abdominal tuberculosis can present in two primary forms: hypertrophic and ulcerative. The hypertrophic form involves thickening of the intestinal wall, while the ulcerative form leads to the formation of ulcers. Clinically, differentiating abdominal tuberculosis from Crohn's disease can be challenging due to overlapping symptoms and similar radiologic findings. In some cases, empirical anti-tubercular therapy (ATP) may be initiated, with subsequent monitoring for clinical improvement to help distinguish between the two conditions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rectum: The rectum is not a common site for abdominal tuberculosis. Tuberculosis primarily affects the ileocecal region and less frequently involves other parts of the gastrointestinal tract.

 

Option B. Colon: While tuberculosis can affect the colon, it is not the most common site. The ileocecal junction is more frequently involved in abdominal tuberculosis.

 

Option C. Small intestine: Although the small intestine can be affected, the terminal ileum specifically, which is part of the ileocecal junction, is the most common site for tuberculosis within the small intestine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most common site of abdominal tuberculosis is the ileocecal junction, particularly near the terminal ileum. This region's lymphoid tissue creates a favorable environment for Mycobacterium tuberculosis to proliferate.

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic patient presents with acute pain and swelling of the left great toe. There is no history of trauma. Synovial fluid analysis shows raised leukocytes. Lab investigations show normal serum uric acid levels. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Acute gout

 

The patient presents with acute pain and swelling in the left great toe, a common presentation of acute gout. Despite normal serum uric acid levels, the clinical presentation and the findings from the synovial fluid analysis point towards acute gout.

 

Key Findings:

 

  1. Acute Pain and Swelling of the Left Great Toe: This is characteristic of acute gout, especially involving the first metatarsophalangeal (MTP) joint.
  2. No History of Trauma: This excludes traumatic causes of joint pain.
  3. Synovial Fluid Analysis Shows Raised Leukocytes: Indicates an inflammatory arthritis.
  4. Normal Serum Uric Acid Levels: In 30-40% of acute gout cases, serum uric acid levels can be normal due to the uric acid being sequestered in the joint rather than in the bloodstream.

 

Acute Gout is a form of inflammatory arthritis caused by the deposition of monosodium urate crystals in joints, leading to intense pain and swelling. The first MTP joint is the most commonly affected site. Acute gout can present with normal serum uric acid levels, particularly during an acute attack, due to the uric acid being sequestered in the joint.

 

Diagnosis Confirmation: The diagnosis of gout is confirmed by joint aspiration and identification of negatively birefringent needle-shaped crystals under polarized light microscopy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pseudogout: This condition usually presents in elderly individuals and often involves the knee or wrist joints. The presence of chondrocalcinosis on X-ray and the involvement of joints like knee (MC), wrist or MCP joint (NOT first MTP joint) makes pseudogout less likely in this case.

 

Option C. Reactive Arthritis: This condition typically follows a gastrointestinal or genitourinary infection and involves multiple joints. There is no mention of such a history in this patient.

 

Option D. Septic Arthritis: This condition is usually associated with more severe systemic symptoms like fever and a more aggressive clinical course. The patient's presentation does not match the typical features of septic arthritis.

 

Educaitonal Objective:

 

Acute gout can present with normal serum uric acid levels, especially during an acute attack, and the involvement of the first metatarsophalangeal (MTP) joint is highly characteristic of this condition.

questions.text: Anuria in clinical practice is defined as:(NEET PG 2014)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Urine output < 100 ml/hr

 

Explanation:

 

Anuria in clinical practice is defined as the passage of less than 100 ml of urine in a day. This definition is crucial for diagnosing severe kidney dysfunction where the kidneys fail to produce urine. Understanding the definitions of various urine outputs helps in differentiating between different levels of renal impairment.

 

 

  • Anuria: Defined as a urine output of less than 100 ml per day. This condition indicates severe kidney failure and requires immediate medical intervention.
  • Oliguria: Defined as a urine output of less than 400 ml per day, which is the minimum amount of urine needed to excrete daily solute production in a normal metabolic state.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Urine output < 400 ml/hr: Incorrect, as this definition applies to oliguria.

 

Option C. Urine output < 800 ml/hr: Incorrect, as this does not fit the clinical definitions of anuria or oliguria.

 

Option D. Urine output < 1200 ml/hr: Incorrect, as this is above the threshold for normal urine output.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anuria is defined as urine output of less than 100 ml per day, indicating severe kidney dysfunction.

questions.text: A positive direct antiglobulin (Coombs) test indicates:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hemolytic disease of the newborn

 

Explanation:

 

A positive direct antiglobulin test (DAT), also known as the direct Coombs test, indicates that antibodies or complement proteins are bound to the surface of red blood cells. This test is commonly used to diagnose hemolytic disease of the newborn (HDN). HDN occurs when maternal antibodies cross the placenta and target fetal red blood cells, leading to their destruction. This immune-mediated hemolysis results in neonatal anemia and hyperbilirubinemia. The positive DAT confirms the presence of these antibodies on the fetal red blood cells, supporting the diagnosis of HDN.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Congenital red cell aplasia: This is a non-immune condition where there is a failure in red blood cell production, not related to antibody-mediated hemolysis.

 

Option B. Hereditary spherocytosis: This is a non-immune hemolytic anemia caused by a defect in the red cell membrane, leading to spherical-shaped red cells that are prone to hemolysis.

 

Option D. G6PD deficiency: This is a non-immune hemolytic anemia caused by an enzyme deficiency that makes red blood cells more susceptible to oxidative stress.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A positive direct anti-globulin (Coombs) test is indicative of hemolytic disease of the newborn, an immune-mediated condition.

questions.text: On thyroid function test analysis, TSH value was much higher than normal with low free T4. What is the diagnosis? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Primary hypothyroidism

 

HYPOTHYROIDISM

 

Types:

 

  1. Primary Hypothyroidism - Increased TSH with low T4 levels.
  2. Secondary hypothyroidism - TSH can be low, normal or elevated slightly. The latter is due to secretion of immune-active but bio-active forms of TSH. Confirmation of diagnosis is done by detecting low levels of unbound T4.

 

Evaluation of Hypothyroidism:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Subclinical hypothyroidism: Incorrect because subclinical hypothyroidism would show an elevated TSH but normal free T4 levels.

 

Option B. Hyperthyroidism: Incorrect as hyperthyroidism would typically present with low TSH and high free T4 levels.

 

Option C. Secondary hypothyroidism: Incorrect for this scenario because secondary hypothyroidism involves a problem with pituitary TSH production, which does not typically result in a significantly elevated TSH.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The primary hypothyroidism is characterized by high TSH and low free T4 levels, indicating a failure of the thyroid gland itself to produce sufficient hormones.

choices.text: Acute coronary syndrome with low EF

questions.text: Automatic implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (AICD) implantation is done for which of the following conditions? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. All of the above

 

An Automatic Implantable Cardioverter-Defibrillator (AICD) is used for the prevention of sudden cardiac death in patients with various cardiac conditions that predispose them to life-threatening arrhythmias. The indications include:

 

Option A. Brugada syndrome: A genetic disorder that can lead to dangerous ventricular arrhythmias.

 

Option B. Ventricular fibrillation (VF): A life-threatening heart rhythm that results in rapid, inadequate heartbeats.

 

Option C. Acute coronary syndrome (ACS) with low ejection fraction (EF): After a myocardial infarction, patients with significantly reduced EF are at higher risk for ventricular arrhythmias.

 

The device is particularly beneficial in patients with structural heart disease, prior myocardial infarction, and those who have experienced syncope due to undetermined reasons but are found to have inducible ventricular tachycardia or fibrillation during electrophysiological studies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Class I Indications for AICD implantation:

 

  1. LV dysfunction with ejection fraction less than or equal to 35% and NYHA II/III symptoms.
  2. LV dysfunction with ejection fraction less than or equal to 35% due to previous Myocardial Infarction (MI) or at least 40 days post-MI and NYHA II/III symptoms.
  3. LV dysfunction with ejection fraction less than or equal to 30% due to previous Myocardial Infarction (MI) or at least 40 days post-MI.
  4. LV dysfunction with ejection fraction less than or equal to 40% due to previous Myocardial Infarction (MI) or at least 40 days post-MI and inducible VT/VF on EP study (EPS).
  5. Syncope of unknown etiology and inducible VT/ VF on EPS.
  6. Sustained VT in the presence of structural heart disease.
  7. Brugada syndrome.
  8. HCM with > 1 risk factor for SCD.

 

Reference - Harrison 21/Ventricular Arrhythmias/Chapter 252

questions.text: An elderly male patient who is a known case of COPD, hypertension, and diabetes mellitus visits the OPD to review his medications. Which of the following criteria should be followed by the physician during the review?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Beer's criteria

 

Explanation:

 

Beer's criteria is a guideline used by physicians to help improve the safety of prescribing medications for older adults. It is specifically designed to avoid potentially inappropriate medications that can cause adverse drug reactions and interactions in the elderly individuals.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Duke's criteria: Used for diagnosing infective endocarditis.

 

Option B. Light criteria: Used for diagnosing exudative pleural effusions.

 

Option D. Jones criteria: Used for diagnosing acute rheumatic fever.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Beer's criteria should be used by physicians to review and manage medications in elderly patients to minimize the risk of adverse effects and drug interactions.

questions.text:
A female with nephrotic syndrome underwent a renal biopsy. Which of the following statements is correct? (INICET MAY 2023)

 

  1. FSGS cannot be diagnosed by a percutaneous renal biopsy
  2. Patient should be observed for 24 hours following biopsy
  3. Dark red clots in the urine following a biopsy indicate a hematoma
  4. Patients with features of systemic amyloidosis and renal involvement can undergo abdominal fat pad biopsy instead of renal biopsy
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 2,3,4

 

Following a renal biopsy, it is crucial to monitor the patient for potential complications, including bleeding and hematoma formation.

 

2. Observation post-biopsy: Patients should be observed for 24 hours following a renal biopsy to monitor for complications such as bleeding or infection.

 

3. Dark red clots in urine: Dark red clots in the urine following a biopsy can indicate a hematoma. This is a potential complication that needs to be monitored.

 

4. Abdominal fat pad biopsy: Patients with systemic amyloidosis and renal involvement can undergo an abdominal fat pad biopsy as an alternative to a renal biopsy. This method can help diagnose systemic amyloidosis with less risk compared to a renal biopsy.

 

Other Option:

 

1. FSGS cannot be diagnosed by a percutaneous renal biopsy: This statement is incorrect. Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) can indeed be diagnosed by a percutaneous renal biopsy. The biopsy helps in identifying the characteristic histological changes associated with FSGS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Post-biopsy observation, recognition of biopsy-related complications, and alternative biopsy methods for systemic amyloidosis are essential in nephrotic syndrome management.

questions.text: A patient presented with the complaints of chest pain. Which among the following is the best investigation to diagnose MI within 2-4 hours? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Troponin â T

 

Troponin-T is the most sensitive and specific biomarker available for diagnosing myocardial infarction (MI) within the early hours of symptom onset. It begins to rise within 3-4 hours of myocardial damage, peaks at around 12-48 hours, and remains elevated for up to 7-10 days, making it highly useful for early diagnosis and detection of recent heart damage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. LDH: it is a less specific enzyme that may be elevated in many types of tissue damage and is not ideal for early diagnosis of MI.

 

Option C. CKMB: it rises within 4-8 hours of myocardial injury, making it less useful than Troponin-T in the very early stages post-symptom onset.

 

Option D. BNP: it is primarily used to assess heart failure and is not a primary marker for acute myocardial infarction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Rise by >20%of troponin is used for diagnosis of Reinfarction

 

Newer biomarkers: HFABP, miRNA1,21,33

 

Reference - (Cardiology/Biomarkers, MI)

choices.text: Acute motor axonal neuropathy
Acute inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy
Acute motor sensory axonal neuropathy
Miller Fisher syndrome

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common type of Guillain-Barre syndrome? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Acute inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy

 

Acute inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy (AIDP) is the most common form of Guillain-Barre syndrome (GBS) in the United States and Europe. It presents with rapidly ascending motor weakness and, at times, sensory disturbances in the form of paresthesia. The pathological hallmark of AIDP is the demyelination of peripheral nerves, leading to slow nerve conduction velocities as detected on electromyography.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute motor axonal neuropathy (AMAN): While AMAN is more common in certain regions like East Asia, it is less prevalent than AIDP in most parts of the world. AMAN is characterized by the involvement of motor fibers without significant demyelination.

 

Option C. Acute motor sensory axonal neuropathy (AMSAN): Similar to AMAN but involves both motor and sensory fibers. It is generally more severe but less common than AIDP.

 

Option D. Miller Fisher syndrome: A rare variant of GBS that is characterized by ataxia, areflexia, and ophthalmoplegia. It is considered a variant of GBS associated with anti-GQ1b antibodies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

AIDP is the most common type of GBS presenting with ascending motor weakness with occasional distal sensory paresthesia due to demyelination of posterior column.

 

Axonal variants:

 

  • AMAN (Acute motor axonal neuropathy): GM1a, GD1a    
  • AMSAN (Acute motor & sensory axonal neuropathy): GM1a, GD1a         

 

Other variants

 

  • Acute motor conduction block neuropathy: GM1a, GD1a
  • Pharyngo-cervico-branchial variant: GT1a
  • Miller-Fischer variant: GQ1b >> GT1a
  • Acute ataxic neuropathy: GQ1b >> GT1a
  • Pure sensory ataxic variant: GD1b
  • Bickerstaff brainstem encephalitis (BBE): GQ1 >> GT1a

 

Reference - Adam and Viktor/Peripheral neuropathy/GBS page 1322

questions.text: A 65-year-old female patient weighing 60 kg is on mechanical ventilation for ARDS secondary to urosepsis. The respiratory parameters are as follows: tidal volume- 360 mL; frequency- 30 breaths/min; PEEP- 5 cm of H2O; and FiO2- 90%. The arterial blood gas findings are as follows: paO2- 50 mmHg; paCO2- 38 mmHg and pH- 7.38. What is the next step? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Increase PEEP

 

Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS) requires careful management of mechanical ventilation settings to optimize oxygenation while minimizing lung injury. The patient's current settings and blood gas findings suggest hypoxemia (paO2 of 50 mmHg) with an FiO2 of 90%. The goal in managing ARDS is to maintain adequate oxygenation (paO2 > 60 mmHg) while reducing the FiO2 to less than 60% to avoid oxygen toxicity.

 

Increasing PEEP is the best option to improve oxygenation. PEEP helps to keep alveoli open, improving gas exchange and oxygenation. By increasing PEEP, we can potentially increase the paO2 and eventually reduce the FiO2 to safer levels.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Reduce FiO2: Although reducing FiO2 is a long-term goal to prevent oxygen toxicity, it is not advisable to reduce it immediately because the patient is currently hypoxemic (paO2 of 50 mmHg).

 

Option B. Increase tidal volume: Not appropriate as it can increase the risk of ventilator-induced lung injury in ARDS patients. The current tidal volume is within the safe range (360 mL), which is appropriate for a 60 kg patient as it falls within the recommended range of 4-6 mL/kg for ARDS patients to prevent ventilator-induced lung injury.

 

Option C. Increase respiratory rate: Increasing the respiratory rate is not necessary in this situation as the paCO2 (38 mmHg) and pH (7.38) indicate normal ventilation and no significant respiratory acidosis (paCO2 is normal).

 

Educational Objective:

 

In ARDS management, if the patient remains hypoxemic despite a high FiO2, the next step is to increase the PEEP to improve oxygenation while maintaining lung-protective ventilation strategies.

choices.text: Inclusion body myositis

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presented with difficulty in activities like climbing stairs, getting up from a chair, and combing hair. Violaceous erythema of the upper eyelids was noted. What is the most probable diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dermatomyositis

 

The patient's symptoms of difficulty in climbing stairs, getting up from a chair, and combing hair suggest proximal muscle weakness, a key feature of myopathy. The presence of violaceous erythema of the upper eyelids, known as heliotrope rash, strongly indicates dermatomyositis.

 

Dermatomyositis is characterized by both muscle inflammation and distinctive skin rashes, and it is commonly associated with anti-Mi-2 antibodies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Inclusion body myositis: Typically presents with asymmetric muscle weakness and does not usually involve skin rashes like dermatomyositis.

 

Option C. Polymyositis: Also involves proximal muscle weakness but lacks the characteristic skin manifestations seen in dermatomyositis.

 

Option D. Scleroderma: Primarily affects the skin with hardening and tightening but does not typically present with proximal muscle weakness or the specific rash of dermatomyositis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Proximal muscle weakness combined with characteristic skin rashes, such as heliotrope rash, is indicative of dermatomyositis.

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient with type 2 diabetes mellitus is being evaluated for medications to manage their condition and prevent renal complications. Which of the following drugs will not delay progression of renal disease? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hydrochlorothiazide

 

Hydrochlorothiazide is a thiazide diuretic primarily used to treat hypertension and edema. It is not specifically known to delay the progression of renal disease in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus. While it helps in managing blood pressure, it does not have the protective renal effects seen with other medications listed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. SGLT2 inhibitors: These drugs, such as dapagliflozin and empagliflozin, have been shown to provide renal protection by reducing the progression of kidney disease in patients with type 2 diabetes. They work by decreasing glucose reabsorption in the kidneys, leading to osmotic diuresis and reduced glomerular hyperfiltration.

 

Option B. Finerenone: This is a non-steroidal mineralocorticoid receptor antagonist (MRA) approved for the treatment of chronic kidney disease in type 2 diabetes. It helps to reduce albuminuria and slows the progression of renal disease.

 

Option D. Angiotensin receptor blockers (ARBs): ARBs, such as losartan and valsartan, are well-known for their renal protective effects. They help reduce proteinuria and slow the progression of diabetic nephropathy by blocking the effects of angiotensin II on the kidneys.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hydrochlorothiazide does not delay the progression of renal disease in patients with type 2 diabetes. In contrast, SGLT2 inhibitors, finerenone, and angiotensin receptor blockers are all known to provide renal protection and slow the progression of diabetic kidney disease.

questions.text: The recommended temperature of water bath for a patient with frost bite is? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 37 degrees C

 

Frostbite should be managed with rapid and complete thawing using a circulating water bath maintained between 37Â°C and 40Â°C. This temperature range is optimal to reverse vascular stasis and initiate reperfusion without causing thermal injury.

 

Thawing at this range is typically performed for 30 to 60 minutes and should be done only when the possibility of refreezing is excluded. Higher temperatures like 42Â°C are not recommended and may worsen tissue injury.

 

Other Option:

 

Option A. 42Â°C: Too hot. It exceeds the upper recommended limit and can risk thermal damage to already compromised tissue.

 

Option C. 32Â°C: Insufficient to produce effective rewarming. Rewarming would be slow and incomplete.

 

Option D. 30Â°C: Ineffective. Tissue remains partially frozen and vulnerable to re-freezing injury.

 

Educational Objective:


Frostbite should be rewarmed in circulating water at 37â40Â°C for 30â60 minutes, avoiding hot air or dry heat.

questions.text: A 48-year-old smoker presents with yellow, copious, foul-smelling sputum that increases significantly in the morning after getting up and on changing posture. He has had this problem for a few years. What will be the first differential diagnosis? (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Bronchiectasis

 

Explanation

 

The correct answer is bronchiectasis. The key features in this case include the presence of copious, foul-smelling sputum that increases significantly in the morning and with postural changes. These features are highly suggestive of bronchiectasis, a condition characterized by chronic dilation and infection of the bronchi. This leads to the production of large amounts of sputum, particularly after changes in posture due to the drainage of secretions from the dilated airways.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Asthma: Typically presents with wheezing, shortness of breath, and a dry or mildly productive cough. Asthma is diagnosed with spirometry, showing reversible airway obstruction.

 

Option B. Pneumonia: Usually presents acutely with fever, cough, and purulent sputum. It is less likely to cause symptoms that have persisted for years.

 

Option D. Lung cancer: May present with chronic cough and hemoptysis but is less likely to produce copious, foul-smelling sputum that increases with postural changes over several years.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bronchiectasis should be considered in patients with chronic, copious, foul-smelling sputum that varies with posture, especially in the context of a history of smoking or recurrent respiratory infections. Recognizing these features can prompt appropriate diagnostic imaging, such as a CT scan showing characteristic tram-track or signet ring appearances.

questions.text: The arterial blood gas analysis findings of a patient are as follows: pH = 7.30, HCO3 = 10 mEq/L, PaCO2 = 20 mmHg, which is suggestive of partially compensated metabolic acidosis. What is the mechanism for the secondary disorder? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Hyperventilation causing increased CO2 washout

 

Explanation:

 

The ABG values indicate metabolic acidosis (low HCO3 with a low pH). The PaCO2 is 20 mmHg, which is lower than the expected value calculated using Winter's formula:

Expected PaCO2 = (1.5 Ã HCO3) + 8 Â± 2 = (1.5 Ã 10) + 8 Â± 2 = 23 Â± 2 mmHg.

The observed PaCO2 (20 mmHg) is lower than the expected value, indicating excessive respiratory compensation through hyperventilation, leading to increased CO2 washout.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hypoventilation causing decreased CO2 washout: This would result in a higher-than-expected PaCO2, worsening acidosis, and does not explain the observed findings.

 

Option C. Increased tubular reabsorption of HCO3-: This mechanism compensates for metabolic acidosis but does not explain the respiratory findings here.

 

Option D. Decreased excretion of H+: This would exacerbate metabolic acidosis rather than represent a compensatory response.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In metabolic acidosis, respiratory compensation via hyperventilation aims to reduce PaCO2, mitigating the acidosis. Comparing measured PaCO2 with the expected value helps identify appropriate or excessive respiratory compensation. Hyperventilation leading to increased CO2 washout is a common compensatory mechanism in metabolic acidosis.

 

Reference: Harrison/Acid-Base Disorders/Chapter 318

questions.text: A triad of skin lesions, asymmetric mononeuritis multiplex and eosinophilia is seen in which of the following conditions? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) EGPA

 

Eosinophilic Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (EGPA), formerly known as Churg-Strauss Syndrome, is characterized by a combination of asthma, eosinophilia, and vasculitis affecting multiple organ systems.

 

The clinical triad of skin lesions (such as purpura or nodules), asymmetric mononeuritis multiplex (manifesting as numbness, pain, or muscle weakness typically in the limbs), and eosinophilia is highly suggestive of this condition. EGPA is a type of ANCA-associated vasculitis but differs from others in its prominent eosinophilic involvement.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cryoglobulinemic vasculitis: Typically associated with hepatitis C infection and features immune complexes in the blood that precipitate in the cold. It commonly presents with palpable purpura, joint pains, and kidney involvement but not typically with eosinophilia.

 

Option B. Polyarteritis nodosa (PAN): A medium vessel vasculitis that may present with similar features including neuropathy and skin lesions but does not typically include eosinophilia as a prominent feature.

 

Option D. Giant cell arteritis (GCA): Primarily affects large vessels, particularly the temporal arteries, and presents with symptoms such as headache, jaw claudication, and potential blindness. It does not feature the triad of skin lesions, mononeuritis multiplex, and eosinophilia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

EGPA is a distinctive form of vasculitis marked by asthma, eosinophilia, and a systemic vasculitis involving skin and nerves among other systems. Its recognition is crucial due to the need for early and aggressive treatment to prevent significant morbidity and mortality.

 

Reference - Harrison/Rheumatology/Vasculitis/Chap 363

questions.text: A 35-year-old female patient with class II pulmonary hypertension presents with a negative vasoreactivity test. Which of the following is used in the next step of management? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ambrisentan

 

Pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH) management depends on the results of the vasoreactivity test. In patients with a negative vasoreactivity test, calcium channel blockers such as nifedipine are not effective. Instead, treatment typically involves the use of endothelin receptor antagonists, phosphodiesterase-5 inhibitors, or prostanoids.

 

For a patient with WHO functional class II PAH and a negative vasoreactivity test, the next step in management often includes endothelin receptor antagonists like Ambrisentan. Ambrisentan works by blocking the effects of endothelin-1, a potent vasoconstrictor, thereby reducing pulmonary vascular resistance and improving symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Iloprost: Iloprost is a prostacyclin analog, used primarily in more advanced stages of PAH (class III or IV) or when other treatments have failed. It is not typically the first-line treatment for class II PAH with a negative vasoreactivity test.

 

Option C. Nifedipine: Nifedipine, a calcium channel blocker, is used in patients with a positive vasoreactivity test. Since this patient has a negative vasoreactivity test, nifedipine is not appropriate.

 

Option D. Epoprostenol: Epoprostenol is another prostacyclin analog used in advanced PAH (class III or IV) or refractory cases. It is not typically used for initial treatment in class II PAH with a negative vasoreactivity test.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In class II and class III pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH), the best option is to use a combination of a phosphodiesterase inhibitor like Tadalafil and an endothelin receptor antagonist like Ambrisentan. Combination therapy is preferred, even though it may not be listed in all options. For refractory class III and class IV PAH patients, prostanoids are used.

questions.text: A morbidly obese diabetic woman is not responsive to metformin therapy. She has a history of pancreatitis and family history of bladder cancer. She does not want to take injections. Which of the following would be suitable to reduce her glucose levels? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Canagliflozin

 

Canagliflozin is a suitable oral medication for a diabetic patient not responding to metformin, especially when she has a history of pancreatitis and a family history of bladder cancer, and prefers to avoid injectable medications. Canagliflozin works by inhibiting the sodium-glucose co-transporter 2 (SGLT2), which helps the kidneys excrete glucose through urine, thus lowering blood glucose levels

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sitagliptin: Not ideal as it has been associated with a risk of acute pancreatitis, which poses a significant risk given her medical history.

 

Option B. Pioglitazone: Should be avoided due to its potential link with bladder cancer, especially considering her family history.

 

Option D. Liraglutide: Although effective in managing diabetes, it is not suitable as it is an injectable medication and the patient prefers to avoid injections. Moreover, it also carries a risk of pancreatitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In choosing diabetes medications for patients with specific health concerns, it's crucial to consider both the efficacy and the side-effect profile of the drug, as well as patient preferences for administration methods to ensure compliance and safety. Canagliflozin is an appropriate choice for this patient due to its oral administration and lower risk concerning her medical history.

questions.text: A patient had a history of TIA and was admitted. 48 hours later he developed severe respiratory difficulty and fever. What is the probable cause? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hospital Acquired Pneumonia

 

Hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP) is defined as pneumonia that occurs 48 hours or more after admission to a hospital and was not present at the time of admission. In this case, the patient developed severe respiratory difficulty and fever 48 hours after being admitted, which fits the definition of HAP. This type of pneumonia is typically caused by bacteria that are more resistant to antibiotics compared to those causing community-acquired pneumonia. Early identification and treatment are crucial for better outcomes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ARDS (Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome): ARDS can cause severe respiratory difficulty and is often associated with significant illnesses or injuries, but the timeline and presence of fever in this case are more consistent with an infection like pneumonia.

 

Option C. Community Acquired Pneumonia: This type of pneumonia occurs outside of a healthcare setting or within 48 hours of hospital admission. Given that the symptoms developed 48 hours after admission, it is not classified as community-acquired.

 

Option D. Aspiration Pneumonia: Aspiration pneumonia occurs when food, liquid, or vomit is inhaled into the lungs, leading to infection. While it can occur in hospitalized patients, the timing and presentation in this case are more suggestive of hospital-acquired pneumonia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pneumonia developing 48 hours or more after hospital admission is classified as hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP).

questions.text: A patient on antidepressants presented to you with hypotension. An ECG was done, which showed wide QRS complexes and right axis deviation. How will you manage this patient? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. IV NaHCO3

 

The patient presents with symptoms indicative of tricyclic antidepressant (TCA) overdose, which includes hypotension, wide QRS complexes, and right axis deviation on the ECG. TCAs can block sodium channels in the heart, leading to QRS widening and the potential for serious arrhythmias. They also have anticholinergic effects, which can contribute to the clinical picture.
